bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Lemuel S. Reed, January 18, 1896

div1.p: Reed provides details of the Reed family genealogy.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Lemuel S. Reed, January 18, 1896

opener.dateline:
No. 5 Cooke Place,
Georgetown, D.C,
Jan. 18th 1896,

div1.p:
I have not been able,
as yet, to visit either the War or
Navy Departments, in order to see
what I could find out about Penel=
ope Reed's pension or John White's
service aboard the Constellation-
I will do this just as soon as my Class-
work will permit me. In the meanwhile,
I have had an answer from Uncle Tom
White as well as one from Cousin Bettie
Reed Holley- First, as to Uncle Tom's an-
swer. He says that Stephen White was
the son of John White and Sallie--
--whose last name he does not recall-
his grand-parents both died before his
birth- Stephen White married Christiana
Hollowell, the daughter of Nathan
Hollowell and his wife, Milly Perry-
He remembers well his grandparents on
his mother's side- He further says that
his father was on the U.S. Frigate, Constel-
lation, but does not think that he
took part in the war of 1812 -
Cousin Bettie writes that she went
to her brother's house, which is in the
Country, and looked over the records of
left by her father- Wilson Reed's father
was William Reed who was married
to Alvié Wilson on Septr 21, 1790.
By this wife, William Reed had two
children, Wilson & Rebecca- The
daughter Rebecca married James
Sutton July 31st 1810- and evidently
your name (“sutton”) comes from
this same James Sutton who married
your father's first cousin- After his
first wife's death, Wm Reed married
again, but she did not tell me as to
any other children by his second wife or her
name either. She further wrote that
her father's records show that William
Reed was the Son of Tully Reed who
was descended from Joseph Reed
who married one of the four daughters
of George Durant, Jr. the son of
George Durant, who settled at about 1660 Durant's Neck.
The other daughters of George Durant, Jr.
married as follows: one married James
Blannt, one married Joseph Cooprew, &
one - Williams. The records further
show that Joseph Reed was descended
from Christopher Reed, whose descendants
owned land at Durant's neck as early as
1680- She says (She is evidently quoting from
the records) that Christopher Reed's Tomb
is now in a state of preservation at
said place - She afterward adds that his
grave has been partly washed into the Sound
but that the slab has been preserved & is
now resting under a gum-tree near
the Sound - I understood you to say that
Christian Reed's grave was the one from
which the gentleman took the slab to make
of it a door-step- It seems that it was really
Christopher Reed's & not Christian's- She
says that the records further state that
Christopher Reed was the Son of Christian
Reed who came to this Country in 1640, and
that Christopher was one of the proprietors Councillors of Lord Proprie-
tors and the first Reed of any prominence in
this Country. Christian Reed returned to
England, but left his Son, Christopher at
Durant's neck where he died & was buried.
Now what do you think of this? I think that it is
extremely interesting - William Reed, Wilson Reed's
father was of course the brother of the father of
Thomas Walk Reed - Do you not think that
very likely that the Wm Reed & James V. Reed,
of whom you spoke to me, were Sons of
this Same William Reed by his second marriage? Or are you certain
that William Reed & James V. were half brothers
(I have it thus written down) and Cousins of
of Wilson Reed & Thomas Walk
Reed? If the letter is true, then
William & James V. are the sons of
the other brother (the 3rd of whom you
spoke) who lived in Beatie Co-
If so, I shouldn't be surprised
if this same brother named one
child “William”, after his brother
William (Wilson Reed's father) & the
other James V- after his other brother,
(the father of Thomas Walk Reed)- If so
Thomas Walk's Reed's father was
named James Reed - of course,
this is only probable, but it is
worth considering after all. Don't
you think so? At any rate, if I
can find whe that Penelope
Wright was a pensioner, I will
clear up this very point-
I have, again, written to Cousin
Bettie, asking her to ascertain whether
she can find the names of her
grandfather, William Reed's brothers-
but have not had time for an answer.
The Union between the Reeds & Durants
in the Early parts of the 18th century is, to me,
exceedingly interesting- I intend to go
down, next May, & look into the subject much
more carefully, for I have always thought that
my ancestors were people of worth and
honesty. But enough of this - we trust
that you and yours are very well-
my! how it rains & snows! the day
is abominable- All join me in
much love to all- write when you
can-
div1.closer:
Affectionately, Walter.
P.S. Wilson Reed was born August 12, 1892.
and died in October, 1860.
